content.description:
Start on the two obvious crimps at about shoulder height in the right-middle part of the red streak. Step up on the edge of the dish an proceed up the red streak until you get to the jug below the roof. Lock in some hand and fist jams and make a slightly committing move over the roof to an angled jug. Work your way up the slopey angled seams in the rock and top out.  

 The crux is getting over the roof as there are not many obvious feet besides jamming the crack. Pads and spotters are helpful for this section.  

 If I am missing any information that might be helpful, please let me know!
content.location: The obvious red streak located on the right side of the Dirty Ernie area.

content.description: Start matched on the left start of Dirty Ernie's Rampage and "go left to jug." As far as I can tell, this means traverse left a few feet to the vaguely square-shaped feature, and then go up to either a big juggy undercling, or a dirty jug-ish feature a little above that.
content.protection: 2 pads. Often (always?) wet and slick near the end. Buyer beware.
content.location: Start a few feet to the left of the obvious crescent-shaped lip. If you're looking at the whole boulder from across the stream, its about two-thirds of the way to the left.

content.description: Start on a slopey crimp rail formed from a horizontal seam/crack, move up using a high right facing flake for a great side cling and small features on the left to maintain compression. Match on the flake and top out by the Tick Boulder.
content.location: 6 ft right of Dirty Ernies Rampage

content.description: Start in the wide crack that faces slightly right by underclinging a block hanging low in the wide crack. Follow the featured crack up as it trends left near the top.
content.location: Far right side of the Dirty Ernies Boulder

content.description: Start deep under the edge of the boulder just to the right of Ernies Revenge with a great undercling for your left hand and a decent crimp for your right.  From there move straight up through powerful finger moves and finish on a jug on the roof.  (Drop off).  Watch your head on the logs.

Different sources disagree on which way this traverses. Until I can learn more: either start to the left of Gabor's V6 and traverse right all the way around the corner and top out above the water, or sit start on the far right and traverse left to the left of Gabor's V6. Shown going left to right in the picture.
content.protection: As many pads and spotters as you need for a long traverse over perpetually wet rock and fast-running water. I also scared a huge wolf spider out of a crack a while back, so whatever you personally require to deal with that...
content.location: Traverse of the entire Dirty Ernie boulder, you can't miss it.

content.description: Same as Dirty Ernie's Revenge, but when you get to the left start hold of Dirty Ernie's Rampage, do not continue right into the right hand start hold for Dirty Ernie's Rampage. Instead go up direct right hand to a bad pinch then bump to a better pinch. (Taken from 27 Crags and a Dan Michels video)

Same as Dirty Ernie's Revenge, but when you get to the nice ledge, instead of downclimbing into the start holds of Dirty Ernie's Rampage, stay high and move wide and right on slopers and pinches to link up with the end of Dirty Ernie's Revenge.
Start on the far left of the boulder on two good crimps. Traverse right until you reach the left start hold of Dirty Ernie's Rampage, and then finish up on Dirty Ernie's Rampage.
content.location: Start on the far left of the Dirty Ernie boulder.

content.description: Start on the right start hold of "Dirty Ernie's Rampage" and traverse low into "Gabor's V6".  Finish up "Gabor's V6".  Not much info on this one, possibly FA'd by Kensie Whitfield (listed as "Dirty Ernie's Traverse" in one of his videos).  If anyone has any info on this climb, please let me know!

Start on two good crimp rails just to the left of the obvious crescent-shaped ledge. Go straight up using crimp in/on either side of the thin diagonal crack. Finish on a triangular-shaped jug just above the huge horizontal crack. No top out.

 Beta on the start: I've seen it written you can start with a "heinous" left drop knee, or what I can only assume is an equally heinous heel hook on the left start hold, though some say this makes it easier and that the drop knee is more fun.
content.location: Just to the left of the obvious crescent-shaped ledge, in the middle of the Dirty Ernie boulder.

content.description: Start matched on the right start hold of Dirty Ernie's Rampage. Use a high heel hook and crimps to climb straight up and finish with Dirty Ernie's Rampage.(Taken from 27 Crags...Dirty Ernie's Toe seems to be a lower much harder start of this one, but without the left crack system)
content.location: Starts on right hand of Dirty Ernie's Rampage

content.description: Can’t get enough of Baker’s Bean? Wish there was more? Try the sit start - hands in the left facing sidepull from the crack, then move into the start for Baker’s Bean and continue living your best life.
content.location: Left facing sidepull of crack under Baker’s Bean

content.description: Start in a right rising discontinuous crack. Use the crack and an edge to the right of the crack that forms a triangular feature. Follow the crack up and right to the prominent horizontal crack below the large roof. Top out to the right of the roof.
content.location: 3 ft right of One Hefty Soup in the right leaning crack

content.description: Start matched low on the Dirty Ernies Rampage crack. Move up and left with your left hand to the right hand start hold of One Hefty Soup. Then bump right hand to a 1 or 2 finger shallow pocket, step up left on the shallow ledge. Reach left hand overhead to an odd finger stack pocket and reach out right to a shallow side cling. Reset your feet and throw for the horizontal crack below the overhung roof above to finish.
content.location: Immediately right of One Hefty Soup

content.description: Just down stream from the Tick Boulder on a beach of large pebbles. This is the furthest downstream area on the south bank, after this there are no more rocks in the water (end of the fall line).
